content.description: Off-width going all the way up. Can use both sides.
content.protection: Top rope can be setup from above by slinging trees.  Anchor line is helpful as trees are 5-10 feet back from top of route.
content.location: On the Main Wall to the right of Samson the Otter.

content.description: Fun boulder/variation to the start of Can't Trust the Weatherman. Start under the overhang on a sloper.  Big moves up to the juggy holds on the ridge-like formation. Don't use the side pull jug on the left - out of bounds. Using this as the start to Can't Trust the Weatherman makes a fun variation that'll pump you out for the rest of the journey up, about 5.10d.
content.location: On the main wall.  Right of Can't Trust the Weatherman. Use photos for reference.

content.description: A challenging and slippery boulder problem that gives the route a 5.10a rating begins the route followed by slippery face climbing on sloppy edges to the top. This route was the first FA put up the in area.
content.protection: Trees at top accessible by foot.
content.location: To the left of Writer's Block.  Reference wide angle photo.
Left of Samson the Otter on the left face.

content.description: Sit start on the short arete on the left side of the overhang follow the crack up and to the left to the small ledge. From there go straight up, veering right for the finish. Probably one of the best routes on the wall.
content.protection: Tie to trees at the top
content.location: To the right of the two large cracks, start to the left of the undercut.

content.description: Start matched on the big hold. Traverse left to the right facing undercling, then use the pockets up and to the left to make your way up to the ledge. Keep your feet on the right side of the crack while you climb up.
content.location: On the left side of the main wall, before the rock changes. The start is under a roof that is about 7 feet high and the route intersects with the starts of Can't Trust The Weatherman and LEAF!!

content.description: Start low. Find the good ledges to pull big move over the roof and cruise to the top. For the brave (read: ballsy), it could be done as a boulder which ends with pulling over the roof.*Potential loose block around this route - be careful*
content.protection: Top rope. Could be a tall boulder if you have pads
content.location: Start is under the large overhanging roof west of the main wall. Left of Happiness Lake

content.description: Two hand sit start, climb the crack to the ledge, follow the round arete type feature up to the top using left hand side-pulls and small horizontal ledges. Top out for extra spice
content.protection: Some trees at top to tie to.
content.location: Right of two large cracks, on the left side on the undercut. Same start as Can't Trust the Weatherman.

climbs.name: Happiness Lake
climbs.fa: Logan Pashby; First Lead: Brady Verbsky April 2020

content.description: Start to the right of the overhang. See photo for exact start.  Follow bolts.
content.protection: Trees for top rope accessible by foot. Three bolts to two bolt anchor, all GI.
content.location: Start to the right of the overhang.  Don't follow the crack.

content.description: Hand jam the starting move. Follow the crack up over a slight overhang.  Follow the line in the topo photo.
content.protection: Trees for anchors at the top
content.location: To the left of the Samson the Otter.  Shares the same start as Jelly Beans for Power.

content.description: Fun moves. Great rock.  Start at the darker rock band in the middle of Shipwreck Rock and go straight up.  Pretty obvious holds.  Crux is at the top.  Make sure to top out at the highest point on the wall - it's the best part.Could be a pretty high-ball boulder problem as well - landing is ok.
content.protection: Trees at the top. Access to the right and up.
content.location: In the middle of Shipwreck Rock, to the right of the Main Face.

content.description: A good route with some big, powerful moves and fun holds. Start under the crevice and go straight up. Right under where the two sides of the crevice meet, there is a small triangle. The savvy climber will find a good undercling hidden about 4 inches within. Continue up the spine on the right side for a couple moves, find some juggy side pulls, and work your way up. Top out for an extra dose of fun. NOTE: All of the left side of the crevice is off route.
content.protection: Tie off to trees up top
content.location: You're asking for directions to the G-Spot? Telling you would ruin the fun!(on a serious note, if you reference the pictures, it should be obvious. The crevice is pretty hard to miss)

content.description: Tough boulder problem up and over the ledge, then pumpy moves to the finish. Start with hands on the low ledge, then match the bad, right-facing side pull. From there, reach far out right and back to the ledge to a jug, shift over and pull. There are a couple different options of holds that will help you get over the roof and past the crux, climber's choice. Once over the ledge, stay to the right of the big crack on slightly overhanging, decent holds. Don't fall here, because getting the boulder problem crux but not sending would be really embarrassing.
content.protection: Top rope off trees on top
content.location: Look for the overhanging roof just to the right of the large crevice on the east end of the main wall. Desperation is the farthest right route on the main wall.

content.description: Continue right away with some bouldery moves.  Stay right of the flake about 15 feet up that belongs to LEAF!! and stay right to the finish.
content.location: Left of Sampson the Otter and right of the Legoland area.

content.description: Probably one of, if not the best, hard route on the wall. Fun, powerful moves on the bottom, a heel hook, two (!) kneebars, and a sketchy topout all packed into 30 feet of pure Penokean climbing. What more can you ask for? Note: To the right and left of the cracks creating the "V" is off route. Beta incoming!Start at the bottom of the V and climb the right face using decent left hands and your right hand side pulling the right crack. Pull a big move to the horizontal, incut ledges just under the overhang. You can throw a knee bar to help this move. From there, gain the good ledges just over the top of the overhang, jam the left heel hook, and reach out for the large side pull on the left. Continue to the overhanging boulder thing on top. Top out for the full experience (and 3 feet of extra climbing).
content.protection: Trees for anchors up top. A static line is recommended as the trees are 10-15 feet back from the wall.
content.location: Between Lego Land (blocky section of wall) and the Main Wall is a small section of rock identified by the two cracks that make a "V" shape. Aerial climbs the right side of the V.

content.description: A secluded sandstone crag in a small, wooded Northern Wisconsin valley in the area known as the "Blue Hills."  The main section of the crag has a length of about 100 feet and an average height of about 25 feet.  Up and down the valley where it lies, there are numerous opportunities for bouldering.  The Blue Hills are the remains of an ancient mountain range, called the Penokean Mountains that ran from Niagra Falls through Northern Wisconsin. A couple of sections are currently being cleaned.  The rock around LEAF!! (5.10a) is generally clean and great for climbing.  Golden Days (5.10b), while a shorter route, is an excellent choice to test out your reach on great holds.  Bolts were just added to Happiness Lake (5.8+) and hopefully more will be added soon.  A perfect spring or fall training ground for those in Northern Wisconsin, as summer climbing here is almost impossible with the amount of mosquitoes. If you plan on climbing here regularly, it may be helpful to familiarize yourself with the locations of the other geological landmarks in the area i.e. the Felsenmeer and Devil's Kettle. It is not uncommon for a group of lost hikers to stumble upon the Penokean.*Note: route grades may be in need of adjustment
